edu.stanford.cs.pptx

Class PPShape

  • Object
    • edu.stanford.cs.pptx.PPShape
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    PPFreeform, PPGroup, PPLine, PPPicture, PPTextShape

    public abstract class PPShape
extends Object
    This abstract class represents the top of the hierarchy that includes all of the "shapes" that can appear on a PowerPoint slide. As with any abstract class, you cannot create an object of class PPShape but instead create an object of one of its concrete subclasses, each of which inherits the properties common to all shapes.

    As an example, you can construct a PPRect object and assign it to a PPShape variable like this:

        PPShape shape = new PPRect(100, 100, 200, 50);

    • Method Detail

      • setName

        public void setName(String name)
        Sets the name for this shape. This name appears in the PowerPoint Custom Animation dialog and makes it much easier to identify the individual shapes on a slide.
        Parameters:
        name - The new name for this shape

      • getName

        public String getName()
        Returns the name for this shape. In no name has been set, the name is a string in the form 
            class#id
        Returns:
        The name for this shape

      • getTypeName

        public String getTypeName()
        Returns the type name of this shape.

        The type name of this shape

      • setOptions

        public void setOptions(String str)
        Sets various optional parameters for this shape from an option string consisting of key names (or key/value pairs for some options) in one of the following forms: 
            /key
        or 
            /key:value
        For example, if you have created a PPRect called myBox, you can set its fill color and line weight like this: 
            myBox.setOptions("/fillColor:BLUE/lineWeight:1.5");
        The list of available options depends on the shape and are detailed in the documentation of the individual shape types.
        Parameters:
        str - The option string used to set the options

      • setSlide

        public void setSlide(PPSlide slide)
        Sets the slide to which this shape belongs.
        Parameters:
        slide - The slide to which this shape belongs

      • getSlide

        public PPSlide getSlide()
        Returns the PPSlide object to which this shape belongs. Before a shape is added to a slide, the getSlide method returns null.
        Returns:
        The slide to which this shape belongs

      • addAnimation

        public void addAnimation(String str)
        Adds an animation to the shape. Animations are specified using a string that begins with the effect name, possibly followed by a set of key names (or key/value pairs for some options) in one of the following forms: 
            /key
        or 
            /key:value
        For example, you can add a simple "Appear" animation effect to a shape using the following code (although you can also use the appear method): 
            shape.addAnimation("Appear");
        Similarly, you can specify a "Checkerboard" effect that moves across the shape triggered 2.0 seconds after the previous effect completes like this: 
            shape.addAnimation("Checkerboard/across/afterPrev/delay:2.0");
        A complete list of the implemented animations and their options is available here.
        Parameters:
        str - The effect name, optionally followed by options

      • appear

        public void appear()
        Adds an Appear animation to this object, using the default trigger of /onClick.

      • appear

        public void appear(String options)
        Adds an Appear animation to this object, using the specifed options string. If no trigger action is specified, the trigger is assumed to be /onClick.
        Parameters:
        options - The option string for the animation

        Parameters:

      • setMotionPathSpeed

        public void setMotionPathSpeed(double pixelsPerSecond)
        Sets the default speed for motion path animations involving this shape. Whenever you call the move or moveTo methods to move this shape on the window, the shape will move at the specified speed unless that value is overridden explicitly. Setting a speed means that objects move at a constant rate, independent of the length of the motion.
        Parameters:
        pixelsPerSecond - The speed of the object

      • getMotionPathSpeed

        public double getMotionPathSpeed()
        Returns the motion path speed for this shape in pixels per second.
        Returns:
        The motion path speed for this shape in pixels per second

      • move

        public void move(double dx,
                 double dy)
        Adds a motion path animation that moves this shape the specified distance from its current location in each dimension. This form of the move method uses the most common options for the motion path segment, which indicate that the shape should move at its current speed (as set by setMotionPathSpeed and that the animation should begin immediately after the preceding one. For more fine-grained control of the motion path, use the version of move that uses an additional parameter to specify options.
        Parameters:
        dx - The distance this object moves in the x direction
        dy - The distance this object moves in the y direction

      • move

        public void move(double dx,
                 double dy,
                 String options)
        Adds a motion path animation that moves this shape the specified distance from its current location in each dimension. This form of the move method allows the caller to specify additional options, as follows:
        /afterPrev Indicates that this motion path segment should start when the preceding animation effect finishes; /afterPrev is the default for motion paths.
        /withPrev Indicates that this motion path segment should run in parallel with the preceding animation effect.
        /onClick Indicates that this motion path segment should start when the user clicks the mouse.
        /speed:pixels/sec Indicates that the shape should move at the specified speed, overriding the default speed of the object. The speed value is measured in pixels per second.
        /duration:seconds Indicates that the motion path should take the specified time, overriding the speed of the object. To move a shape instantly, specify a duration of 0.
        /acc Indicates that the shape should accelerate at the beginning of its motion, giving a smoother feel to the animation. In general, the /acc option appears only on the first segment of a chained motion path.
        /dec Indicates that the shape should decelerate at the end of its motion, giving a smoother feel to the animation. In general, the /dec option appears only on the last segment of a chained motion path.
        Parameters:
        dx - The distance this object moves in the x direction
        dy - The distance this object moves in the y direction
        options - A string specifying additional options about the motion

      • moveTo

        public void moveTo(double x,
                   double y)
        Adds a motion path animation that moves this shape to a new location. This method is similar to the move(double,double) method except that the motion is indicated by specifying the final location rather than the dx and dy displacements.
        Parameters:
        x - The final x coordinate after the motion
        y - The final y coordinate after the motion

      • moveTo

        public void moveTo(double x,
                   double y,
                   String options)
        Adds a motion path animation that moves this shape to a new location. This method is similar to the move(double,double,String) method except that the motion is indicated by specifying the final location rather than the dx and dy displacements.
        Parameters:
        x - The final x coordinate after the motion
        y - The final y coordinate after the motion
        options - A string specifying additional options about the motion

      • curveTo

        public void curveTo(double x1,
                    double y1,
                    double x2,
                    double y2,
                    double x3,
                    double y3)
        Adds an animation to move this shape along the specified Bezier curve. The control points of the curve are the current point, the two intermediate points given by (x1, y1) and (x2, y2), and the final point (x, y).
        Parameters:
        x1 - The x coordinate of the first Bezier point
        y1 - The y coordinate of the first Bezier point
        x2 - The x coordinate of the second Bezier point
        y2 - The y coordinate of the second Bezier point
        x3 - The final x coordinate after the motion
        y3 - The final y coordinate after the motion

      • curveTo

        public void curveTo(double x1,
                    double y1,
                    double x2,
                    double y2,
                    double x3,
                    double y3,
                    String options)
        Adds an animation to move this shape along the specified Bezier curve. The control points of the curve are the current point, the two intermediate points given by (x1, y1) and (x2, y2), and the final point (x3, y3). This version allows the client to specify options.
        Parameters:
        x1 - The x coordinate of the first Bezier point
        y1 - The y coordinate of the first Bezier point
        x2 - The x coordinate of the second Bezier point
        y2 - The y coordinate of the second Bezier point
        x3 - The final x coordinate after the motion
        y3 - The final y coordinate after the motion
        options - A string specifying additional options about the motion

      • getLocation

        public Point2D getLocation()
        Returns the current location of the shape. In the typical case in which no motion paths are involved, this location is simply the initial location. If an object is moving as part of a motion path sequence, this method returns the current location on the path. Note that there is no symmetric setLocation method to ensure that the intent is clear. If you want to set the initial location of a shape, you need to call setInitialLocation; to move it to a new location using a motion path, use moveTo.
        Returns:
        A Point2D indicating the current location of the shape

        public double getX()
        Returns the current x coordinate of the shape.

        The current x coordinate of the shape

        Returns:

      • getInitialLocation

        public Point2D getInitialLocation()

        Returns:
        A Point2D indicating the initial location of the shape

      • setInitialLocation

        public void setInitialLocation(double x,
                               double y)
        Sets the initial location for this shape on the slide. Note that this method affects the location at which the shape appears on the initial slide and does not have anything to do with motion paths.
        Parameters:
        x - The initial x coordinate for the shape
        y - The initial y coordinate for the shape

      • setInitialLocation

        public void setInitialLocation(Point2D loc)
        Sets the initial location for this shape on the slide. Note that this method affects the location at which the shape appears on the initial slide and does not have anything to do with motion paths.
        Parameters:
        loc - A Point2D value specifying the initial location

      • setBounds

        Parameters:

        y - The initial y coordinate for the shape
        width - The desired width of the shape
        height - The desired height of the shape
